title: New paper alert: Protein folding with an all-to-all trapped-ion quantum computer
description: Excited to announce our new experimental work, in collaboration with IonQ, on higher-order binary optimization using BF-DCQO. In particular, we tackle protein folding with up to 12 amino acids, one of the largest implementations to date on a quantum computer, max-4-SAT at the computational phase transition with up to 36 qubits, and a fully connected spin-glass problem using 36 qubits. arXiv:2506.07866

title: IBM Quantum Partner Forum in London
description: Attended and gave a talk on 'Runtime Quantum Advantage with BF-DCQO' at the IBM Quantum Partner Forum in London. Video

title: Low autocorrelation binary sequence (LABS)
description: Comparison of a random binary sequence versus the optimal low-autocorrelation sequence of length 30. In the animation, you can see that the optimal sequence exhibits a single dominant peak at zero lag, with all other side-lobes suppressedâ€”unlike the random sequence, whose autocorrelation side-lobes fluctuate widely.

title: Quantum Optimization Working Group Meeting: Liverpool
description: Attended the annual Quantum Optimization Working Group Meeting in Liverpool, UK, with insightful discussions on the latest quantum optimization advancements. Began a new collaboration on an exciting project.

title: New paper alert: Runtime quantum advantage with BF-DCQO
description: Experimental demonstration of runtime quantum advantage for 156-qubit HUBO problems on superconducting quantum processors using the BF-DCQO algorithm, benchmarked against simulated annealing and CPLEX. arXiv:2505.08663

title: New paper alert: Sequential Quantum Computing
description: We propose and experimentally demonstrate sequential quantum computing (SQC), a paradigm that utilizes multiple homogeneous or heterogeneous quantum processors in hybrid classical-quantum workflows. In this manner, we are able to overcome the limitations of each type of quantum computer by combining their complementary strengths. arXiv:2506.20655

title: Protein Folding on Trapped-Ion Quantum Computer
description: The animation shows the 11-residue head-activator peptide QPPGGSKVILF folding on a tetrahedral lattice, using the 2000 measurement shots collected in the final BF-DCQO iteration on the IonQ Forte all-to-all trapped-ion processor: each frame presents one sampled conformation, the blue staircase curve plots the full set of conformations sorted from highest to lowest computed energy, and the orange dot highlights the structure currently in view, giving a clear snapshot of how the final quantum sample spans the energy landscape from less-favourable folds down to the global minimum.
